sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The Glade application enables you to create graphical user interfaces (GUIs) from the GTK+ and GNOME libraries. Glade enables you to create source code for your GUIs in the following languages:

listitem.para: Ada
C

sect1.para: Glade generates C code by default. You might have to install additional packages to generate code in the other languages.

You can also use Glade in conjunction with libglade to dynamically create GUIs from the XML description file that Glade creates. For large applications, the use of libglade is recommended rather than C code generation.

The GTK+ and GNOME libraries provide an extensive collection of user interface building blocks such as text boxes, dialog labels, numeric entries, check boxes, and menus. These building blocks are called widgets.
Glade enables you to do the following tasks in a simple manner:

listitem.para: Place widgets correctly in a GUI.
Assign functionality to the widgets.

sect1.para: You choose widgets from a palette of available widgets, and place the widgets into your project. You edit the widget properties in the Properties window. You also use the Properties window to add connections between your widgets and externally-written code.
You can obtain Glade from the following locations:

listitem.para:
Links are provided on the following Glade download site for various package formats:
http://glade.gnome.org/download.html

For information about how to get Glade from the GNOME CVS server, see the
GNOME CVS page at the following location: http://developer.gnome.org/tools/cvs.html

sect1.para: Glade features a GNOME support option. However, to use this feature you need to have a recent version of the GNOME desktop environment. If you do not have a recent version of the GNOME desktop environment, you can disable the support feature when you compile Glade. To disable the support feature, include the following option in the compile command: --disable-gnome.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start Glade in the following ways:

listitem.para: Execute the following command: glade-2
Choose ApplicationsProgrammingGlade Interface Designer.

sect1.para: When you start Glade, the following windows appear:
Glade consists of the following windows:

listitem.para: The Glade window contains a menubar and a toolbar. You can use either the menubar or the toolbar to work with projects. This manual documents functionality from the menubar. The Glade window also contains a list of the top-level widgets that are defined for the current project.
The Palette window contains the widgets that you can use to build an interface. You add widgets from the Palette window to your project.
The Properties window enables you to manipulate the properties of widgets, such as their size, color, signal masks, and so on.
All widgets in a user interface are organized into the Widget Tree. You can view the path up the tree from a specific widget to the root widget, or top-level widget.
The Clipboard enables you to remove items from your project, and paste items back into your project.
These are the windows of the application that you are designing.

sect1.title: Viewing Glade Windows
sect1.para: You can use the View menu to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: Display hidden windows.
Raise obscured windows to the top of the window stack.

sect2.title: To View the Palette Window
sect2.para:
Choose
View Show Palette .

sect2.title: To View the Properties Window
sect2.para:
Choose
View Show Property Editor .

sect2.title: To View the Widget Tree
sect2.para:
Choose
View Show Widget Tree .

sect2.title: To View the Clipboard
sect2.para:
Choose
View Show Clipboard .

sect1.title: Working With Projects
sect1.para: The typical stages in a Glade project are as follows:

listitem.para: Select the widgets that you require from the Palette window. Insert the widgets into your project. Right-click on a widget to view a popup menu from which you can choose to perform actions on that widget.

note.para: Take care when you perform actions on widgets that have children. If you delete the parent widget, you also delete the children.

listitem.para: While you construct the interface, you use the Properties window to manipulate the various settings and dimensions of the widgets.

When the interface is finished, you save the project and build the source files that generate the user interface. You can then integrate the source code with your project logic. The default language for source code is C.

sect2.title: To Create a New Project
sect2.para: Perform the following steps to create a new project:

listitem.para:
Choose
Project New .
In the Glade dialog box, click OK.
In the New Project dialog box, click on the appropriate button to select a new GTK+ project or a new GNOME project.
In the Palette window, click on the window widget.
You can now add widgets for your application to the new project window. See for more information about how to use widgets to build your application interface.

sect2.title: To Open an Existing Project
sect2.para:
Choose
Project Open . An Open Project dialog appears, in which you specify the filename of the project that you want to open.

sect2.title: To Save a Project
sect2.para:
Choose
Project Save . If this is the first time you are saving your project, a Project Options dialog appears, containing default values. See for more information about setting project options.
If you have previously specified the project settings, Glade saves your current project without comment.

sect2.title: To Generate Source Code For Your Project
sect2.para:
Choose
Project Build . If this is the first time you are saving your project, a Project Options dialog appears, containing default values. See for more information about setting project options.
If you have previously specified the project settings, Glade outputs code without comment.

sect2.title: To Set Project Options
sect2.para:
Choose
Project Options . The
Project Options dialog appears, containing default values. If you have previously specified the project settings, those settings appear in the Project Options fields. See for more information about setting project options.

sect2.title: To Exit Glade
sect2.para: Save your project before you exit the application.

To exit Glade, choose
Project Quit . Glade asks you if you want to quit the application, but does not query you to save unsaved project data.

sect1.title: Setting Your Project Options
sect1.para: Use only ASCII characters for names of files and directories in the Project Options dialog. Other systems might use different character encodings for the names of files and directories, which can cause problems. You can set options in the following functional areas in the Project Options dialog:

listitem.para: Enter the location of your project in this field. Click on Browse to select a location directory from your file system.
Type the name of your project in this text box. When you edit this information, the program name and project filename change automatically.

Type the name of the executable for your project in this text box. Glade uses this executable to generate code for your project. When you edit this information, the project file changes automatically.
Type the filename for your project in this text box. All of your project information is stored in this file.
Use the text box to specify where you want Glade to build source code for the project.
Use the text box to specify where Glade can find any image files that are used in the project.

sect3.title: Language
sect3.para: Pick the programming language that you want Glade to use to build source code for the project.

sect3.title: Enable Gnome Support
sect3.para: Select this check box if you want Glade to build source code that uses the GNOME libraries.

listitem.para: Select this option to create code that supports GNU gettext for internationalization.
Select this option to create code to set the names for all widgets. This feature is useful if you intend to use GTK+ calls such as gtk_widget_path().
Select this option to make a backup of all your source files when you build new files.
Select this option to create code that supports Help in the GNOME desktop environment.

Select this option to output a file named main.c, which contains a simple bootstrap. The function called by main.c depends on the status of the Enable Gnome Support option:
Option Status
Called Function
Enabled
gnome_init()
Not Enabled
gtk_init()
Select this option to output a file named support.c, which contains utility functions for various tasks, for example:
Create an image file.
Look for a widget by name.
Select this option to output files to support configuration of your project through automake and autoconf. This option creates the following files:

entry.para: Script for building a configure script.
Log of changes you have made in the project.
Template for building a configure script.
Contains general information about the project.
Automake template for the src/ directory.

listitem.para: Use the text box to specify the file where you want Glade to store the code for the user interface.
Use the text box to specify the name of the file where you want Glade to store function prototypes for the user interface code.
Use the text box to specify the name of the file where you want Glade to store signal handler code.
Use the text box to specify the file where you want Glade to store function prototypes for signal handler code.
Use the text box to specify the file where you want Glade to store support function code.
Use the text box to specify the file where you Glade to store function prototypes for the support function code.

sect3.title: Save Translatable Strings
sect3.para: This option is deprecated. Use intltool instead when you want to translate interfaces designed in Glade.

sect2.title: To Select Widgets From the Palette Window
sect2.para: You can work with the widgets in the Palette window in the following ways:

listitem.para: To use selection mode, click on the Selector arrow. The pointer changes to an arrow to indicate that selection mode is active. In this mode, you use the mouse to select widgets in your project. You can then use the Properties window to edit the properties of the widgets. If you hold down the Shift key and repeatedly select a widget, the selection cycles through the widget and all of its parent widgets.
You can also use the widget context menu to select a widget. Right-click on a widget to open the widget context menu.

You can add multiple widgets of a specific type from the Palette to your project by holding down the Control key when you select a widget. You need to click on the Selector arrow or another widget in the Palette to return to normal mode.

To use widget placement mode, select a widget in the Palette window. When you select most widgets, the pointer changes to a pointer-plus-cross. You can then place the widget inside containers, top-level widgets, and so on. After you place a widget, the mode returns to selection mode.

To use top level placement mode, select a defined top-level widget in the Palette window. When you select a top-level widget in the Palette window, the widget appears immediately on your desktop. You can then edit the widget. After you select a top-level widget, the mode returns to selection mode.

sect2.title: To Organize Widgets In Your Project
sect2.para: You use widget containers, or boxes, to layout and organize widgets in your project window. You can choose the following widget containers from the Palette window:

listitem.para: Horizontal Box
Vertical Box
Table
Fixed Positions
Horizontal Button Box
Vertical Button Box
Horizontal Panes
Vertical Panes
Notebook
Frame
Scrolled Window
Viewport

sect2.para: You can nest boxes to create complex layout structures. When you create horizontal and vertical boxes, Glade asks you how many rows or columns to create initially, though rows and columns can easily be added or deleted later.

When you have created all the boxes you require, you can add specific widgets like labels, buttons, and more complicated widgets into the boxes. Notice that Glade packs widgets into the layout which eliminates a lot of tedious work. The use of boxes enables windows to change size to accommodate different size labels in different languages when the application is localized.

sect2.title: To Place a Widget on the Clipboard
sect2.para:
To remove a widget from a parent and place the widget on the clipboard, select the widget then choose
Edit Cut .

sect2.title: To Copy a Widget to the Clipboard
sect2.para:
To copy a widget to the clipboard, select the widget then choose
Edit Copy . The original widget remains attached to the parent.

sect2.title: To Paste a Widget From the Clipboard Into Your Project
sect2.para:
To paste a widget that exists on the clipboard into your project, choose
Edit Paste .

All widgets must have a unique name within Glade. If you cut a widget, and then paste the widget into your project, then the widget and all of the children of the widget keep their original names. If you copy a widget, or paste the widget multiple times into your project, then Glade generates new names for the widget copies.

sect2.title: To Delete a Widget
sect2.para:
To delete a widget from the parent without moving the widget to the clipboard, select the widget then choose
Edit Clear .

sect1.title: Finding Out More About Widgets
sect1.para: Widgets are grouped into the following categories in the Palette window:

listitem.para: This category contains frequently-used GTK+ widgets such as windows and labels.
This category contains widgets such as GtkAlignment, GtkPacker, and GtkCalendar.
This category includes all of the GNOME widgets that Glade supports.

sect1.para: To find out the purpose of a widget in the Palette window, point to the widget to activate a tooltip. For more information about the widgets that Glade supports, see the GTK+ Reference Manual.

listitem.para: Select this option if you want to show a grid when you place a widget in a GtkFixed or GtkLayout container.
Select this option if you want widgets to snap to the grid in a GtkFixed or GtkLayout container.
Select this option to enable the tooltips you have set in your interface. Tooltip display can be a distraction when you are creating an interface within Glade, so you might like to turn them off.
Use the spin box to specify the number of pixels to skip horizontally before drawing a line in the grid.
Use the spin box to specify the number of pixels to skip vertically before drawing a line in the grid.
Use the radio buttons to specify whether to draw the grid with dots or lines.
Use the check boxes to specify the snap behavior in the grid of the left and right edges of a widget.
Use the check boxes to specify the snap behavior in the grid of the top and bottom edges of a widget.
